Efficient Federated Learning over Multiple Access Channel with Differential Privacy Constraints

Amir Sonee amir.sonee@mail.um.ac.ir    Stefano Rini National Chiao Tung University (NCTU), Taiwan
stefano@nctu.edu.tw
Abstract

In this paper, the problem of federated learning (FL) through digital communication between clients and a parameter server (PS) over a multiple access channel (MAC), also subject to differential privacy (DP) constraints, is studied. More precisely, we consider the setting in which clients in a centralized network are prompted to train a machine learning model using their local datasets. The information exchange between the clients and the PS takes places over a MAC channel and must also preserve the DP of the local datasets. Accordingly, the objective of the clients is to minimize the training loss subject to (i) rate constraints for reliable communication over the MAC and (ii) DP constraint over the local datasets. For this optimization scenario, we proposed a novel consensus scheme in which digital distributed stochastic gradient descent (D-DSGD) is performed by each client. To preserve DP, a digital artificial noise is also added by the users to the locally quantized gradients. The performance of the scheme is evaluated in terms of the convergence rate and DP level for a given MAC capacity. The performance is optimized over the choice of the quantization levels and the artificial noise parameters. Numerical evaluations are presented to validate the performance of the proposed scheme.

Index Terms:
Federated Learning, Differential privacy, Multiple access channel, Distributed Stochastic Gradient descent.

I Introduction

The ever-increasing need to process large amounts of data generated by users networks such as wireless sensor networks and mobile networks has spurred the development of joint data processing algorithms and network protocols [1]. As learning is one of the fundamental applications motivating data transfer in such large networks, federated learning (FL) has recently emerged as a promising paradigm for distributed machine learning (ML). In the FL paradigm, a parameter server (PS) aims at training a global model with the federated collaboration of distributed users, also referred to as local learners. The FL model alleviates the need of communicating local data toward the PS by opting to, instead, perform the optimization locally and use consensus over multiple iterations to converge to the optimal solution [2]. One way for this paradigm to be implemented, is by having the PS share the current model estimate with the network users at each communication round. Upon receiving an updated model estimate, the local learners compute the gradients over the local datasets and update the model estimate using stochastic gradient descent (SGD) method. The locally-updated models are then communicated to the PS which merges these estimates to produce an updated central estimate. By repeating these two update steps, i.e. the local model update and the global model update, the clients and the PS can converge to the optimal solution. In practical scenarios, the communication between the PS and the local learners is constrained in either the communication rate, reliability, or connectivity: for this reason authors have considered variation of the basic FL setting also encompassing such communication constraints [3, 4]. The FL model, not only allows a better utilization of computational resources, but also provides some security enhancements. Since the row data is not communicated to the central server, the users’ data is never exposed to the security vulnerability which are intrinsic in especially in wireless communication. Despite this, it has been shown that local gradients may leak some information about the data endangering the privacy of the model [5]. This possible information leakage has made the investigation of privacy for the FL model an issue of considerable significance. Further results including DP analysis of FL model can be found in [6, 7, 8].

Contributions

We provide a theoretical formulation for FL optimization subject to communication and privacy constrains and propose a novel computation and communication scheme that attains learning under communication and privacy constraints. The proposed communication scheme generalizes that of [3] by adding a digital artificial noise to each client’s transmitted message to enhance privacy. Our achievable scheme also generalizes the one in [6] by enabling efficient communication over MAC through multi-level stochastic quantization of gradients. Additionally, we show how the convergence rate of this scheme can be optimized as a function of the quantization levels, and digital noise parameters for a given set of communication and privacy constraints.

II System Model and Problem Formulation

II-A FL model with efficiency and privacy

A distributed learning model over a MAC, as introduced in [3, 4] and shown in Fig. 1, is characterized by a set [n]delimited-[]𝑛[n] of clients communicating with a remote PS over a MAC with the aim of training a machine learning model. The PS is assumed to have a perfect channel toward each client, separately. Learning can be formulated as minimizing the loss function

In order for the above algorithm to guarantee convergence, it is required for the local gradients to have bounded second order moments as ‖𝐠it‖2≤Dtsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑖𝑡2superscript𝐷𝑡\|\mathbf{g}_{i}^{t}\|_{2}\leq D^{t}.

Two constraints that arise naturally in the FL scenario are (i) a constraint on the communication between the clients and the PS, and (ii) a constraint on the privacy of the local datasets. These two additional requirements are mathematically formulated as follows.

(i) – The communication constraint is concerned with the largest rate of reliable communication that can be attained over the channel as expressed by the MAC capacity. For this constraint to be met, at iteration t𝑡t, each client i𝑖i applies a digital transmission approach (D-DSGD), as in [6, 3], by quantizing the local gradients into litsuperscriptsubscript𝑙𝑖𝑡l_{i}^{t} levels with maximum quantized value of Gtsuperscript𝐺𝑡G^{t} and through computing a function QGt,lit:ℝd→ℝd:subscriptQsuperscript𝐺𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑙𝑖𝑡→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑{\rm Q}_{G^{t},l_{i}^{t}}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{d} of its gradient as 𝐪it=QGt,lit​(𝐠it)superscriptsubscript𝐪𝑖𝑡subscriptQsuperscript𝐺𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑙𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑖𝑡\mathbf{q}_{i}^{t}={\rm Q}_{G^{t},l_{i}^{t}}\left(\mathbf{g}_{i}^{t}\right).

(i) – The security constraint is concerned with the local database privacy which, in turn, entails the privacy of the local gradients as aggregated at the PS. For this constraint to be met, one promising way is via the notion of (DP) for the average gradient, as introduced in [10]. DP is a strong measure of privacy that can ensure privacy for the FL model, even after post-processing performed by the PS. In order to alleviate the restrictive need to trust the PS, a local DP (LDP) approach is proposed in which a randomized mechanism is applied by each client contributing some randomness to the quantized local gradient 𝐪itsuperscriptsubscript𝐪𝑖𝑡\mathbf{q}_{i}^{t} before transmission toward the PS. More precisely, this process can be carried out by client i𝑖i at iteration t𝑡t via computing a privacy-preserving mechanism M𝒫it:ℝd→ℝd:subscriptMsuperscriptsubscript𝒫𝑖𝑡→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑{\rm M}_{{\cal P}_{i}^{t}}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{d}, with the set of parameters 𝒫itsuperscriptsubscript𝒫𝑖𝑡{\cal P}_{i}^{t}, on the quantized gradient as 𝐦it=M𝒫it​(𝐪it)superscriptsubscript𝐦𝑖𝑡subscriptMsuperscriptsubscript𝒫𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐪𝑖𝑡\mathbf{m}_{i}^{t}={\rm M}_{{\cal P}_{i}^{t}}\left(\mathbf{q}_{i}^{t}\right). Finally, the perturbed gradient is encoded using a channel coding function of rate Ritsuperscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑡R_{i}^{t}, XRit:ℝd→ℝN:subscriptXsuperscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑡→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑁{\rm X}_{R_{i}^{t}}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{N}, as 𝐱it=XRit​(𝐦it)superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑡subscriptXsuperscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐦𝑖𝑡\mathbf{x}_{i}^{t}={\rm X}_{R_{i}^{t}}\left(\mathbf{m}_{i}^{t}\right).

As a result of this procedure, at iteration t𝑡t, client i𝑖i sends the codeword 𝐱itsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑡\mathbf{x}_{i}^{t} to the PS through N𝑁N channel uses of the (Gaussian) MAC: for this model the input/output relationship is expressed as

𝐲t=∑i∈[n]𝐱it+𝐳t,superscript𝐲𝑡subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑡superscript𝐳𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{y}^{t}=\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbf{x}_{i}^{t}+\mathbf{z}^{t}, (4)

where 𝐳t∼𝒩​(0,𝐈N)similar-tosuperscript𝐳𝑡𝒩0subscript𝐈𝑁\mathbf{z}^{t}\sim{\cal N}\left(0,\mathbf{I}_{N}\right) is the additive white Gaussian noise and the channel inputs at each iteration satisfy the average power constraint

‖𝐱it‖22≤N​Pi,∀i∈[n].formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑡22𝑁subscript𝑃𝑖for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\displaystyle\|\mathbf{x}_{i}^{t}\|_{2}^{2}\leq NP_{i},\ \forall\ i\in[n]. (5)

For error-free decoding of the perturbed gradients at the PS, the rate of transmission by client i𝑖i, Ritsuperscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑡R_{i}^{t}, should not exceed the capacity of the Gaussian MAC. Accordingly, it is required that

∑i∈𝒮Rit≤12​log2⁡(1+∑i∈𝒮Pi)≜C𝒮,∀𝒮⊆[n],formulae-sequencesubscript𝑖𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑡12subscript21subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝑃𝑖≜subscript𝐶𝒮for-all𝒮delimited-[]𝑛\sum_{i\in{\cal S}}R_{i}^{t}\leq\frac{1}{2}\log_{2}\left(1+\sum_{i\in{\cal S}}P_{i}\right)\triangleq C_{{\cal S}},\ \ \forall\ {\cal S}\subseteq[n], (6)

where C𝒮subscript𝐶𝒮C_{{\cal S}} is the sum-capacity of the MAC, from the subset 𝒮𝒮{\cal S} of clients to the PS. Having decoded the perturbed local gradients, the PS next estimates the global gradient by averaging over the decoded gradients as

𝐠¯t=1n​∑i∈[n]𝐦it,superscript¯𝐠𝑡1𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐦𝑖𝑡\mathbf{\overline{g}}^{t}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbf{m}_{i}^{t},\vspace{-1mm} (7)

which is required to release an unbiased estimation of the true global gradient i.e. 𝔼​(𝐠¯t)=𝐠t=∑i∈[n]𝐠it/n𝔼superscript¯𝐠𝑡superscript𝐠𝑡subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑖𝑡𝑛\mathbb{E}\left(\mathbf{\overline{g}}^{t}\right)=\mathbf{g}^{t}=\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbf{g}_{i}^{t}/n. The estimation error is evaluated using the mean square error (MSE) as

Next, the PS proceeds to update and broadcast the parameter vector 𝐰t+1superscript𝐰𝑡1\mathbf{w}^{t+1} to be used for the next iteration by clients over a noiseless link as 𝐰t+1=𝐰t−γt​𝐠¯tsuperscript𝐰𝑡1superscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡superscript¯𝐠𝑡\mathbf{w}^{t+1}=\mathbf{w}^{t}-\gamma^{t}\mathbf{\overline{g}}^{t}.

We refer this algorithm to as locally differential private with quantized stochastic gradients (LDP-QSGD). The performance of LDP-QSGD is evaluated in terms of the convergence rate and LDP addressing the efficiency and privacy of the algorithm, respectively. The convergence of the FL model is measured using |𝔼​(ℓ​(𝐰T))−ℓ​(𝐰∗)|𝔼ℓsubscript𝐰𝑇ℓsuperscript𝐰∗|\mathbb{E}\left(\ell\left(\mathbf{w}_{T}\right)\right)-\ell\left(\mathbf{w}^{\ast}\right)| which is expected to vanish as T𝑇T grows, since the model is learned at the PS and, consequently, at the local learners. The LDP of the model is measured through the amount of indistinguishability in determining whether a mechanism output is generated from two distinct sample points. For any local gradient pair 𝐠i′superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑖′\mathbf{g}_{i}^{\prime} and 𝐠i′′superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑖′′\mathbf{g}_{i}^{\prime\prime} and any subset ℳℳ{\cal M} of 𝖱𝖺𝗇𝗀𝖾​(M)𝖱𝖺𝗇𝗀𝖾M\sf{Range({\rm M})}, this can be formally expressed as the probability of ℳℳ{\cal M} generated by 𝐠i′superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑖′\mathbf{g}_{i}^{\prime} to be within a multiplicative factor of the probability ℳℳ{\cal M} generated by 𝐠i′′superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑖′′\mathbf{g}_{i}^{\prime\prime}:

Pr​(M𝒫​(QD,l​(𝐠i′))∈ℳ)≤eϵ​Pr​(M𝒫​(QD,l​(𝐠i′′))∈ℳ)+δPrsubscriptM𝒫subscriptQ𝐷𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝐠′𝑖ℳsuperscript𝑒italic-ϵPrsubscriptM𝒫subscriptQ𝐷𝑙superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑖′′ℳ𝛿\displaystyle\textsf{Pr}\left({\rm M}_{{\cal P}}\left({\rm Q}_{D,l}\left(\mathbf{g}^{\prime}_{i}\right)\right)\!\in\!{\cal M}\right)\leq e^{\epsilon}\textsf{Pr}\left({\rm M}_{{\cal P}}\left({\rm Q}_{D,l}\left(\mathbf{g}_{i}^{\prime\prime}\right)\right)\!\in\!{\cal M}\right)\!+\!\delta (9)

under which, mechanism MM{\rm M} is called (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿\left(\epsilon,\delta\right) differentially private, [10].

II-B Optimization setting

For the FL model with digital communication over the MAC subject to privacy and efficiency, as described in Sec. II-A, we formulate the following optimization problem. Using LDP-QSGD, this problem aims at determining the optimum quantization levels {lit}i∈[n]subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑙𝑖𝑡𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\{l_{i}^{t}\}_{i\in[n]} of the QSGD scheme for local gradients and noise parameters {𝒫it}i∈[n]subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒫𝑖𝑡𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\{{\cal P}_{i}^{t}\}_{i\in[n]} of the LDP mechanism that maximizes the convergence rate subject to the transmission rates and privacy constraints of clients. More formally

𝒫::𝒫absent\displaystyle{\cal P}: min{lit,𝒫it}i∈[n]subscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑙𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒫𝑖𝑡𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\displaystyle\min_{\left\{l_{i}^{t},{\cal P}_{i}^{t}\right\}_{i\in[n]}} |𝔼​(ℓ¯​(𝐰T))−ℓ¯​(𝐰∗)|,𝔼¯ℓsubscript𝐰𝑇¯ℓsuperscript𝐰∗\displaystyle|\mathbb{E}\left(\bar{\ell}(\mathbf{w}_{T})\right)-\bar{\ell}\left(\mathbf{w}^{\ast}\right)|,
s.t. ϵt≤Δϵ,superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡subscriptΔitalic-ϵ\displaystyle\epsilon^{t}\leq\Delta_{\epsilon},
∑i∈𝒮Rit≤C𝒮,∀𝒮⊆[n]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑖𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑡subscript𝐶𝒮for-all𝒮delimited-[]𝑛\displaystyle\ \sum_{i\in{\cal S}}R_{i}^{t}\leq C_{{\cal S}},\ \forall\ {\cal S}\subseteq[n]

for C𝒮subscript𝐶𝒮C_{{\cal S}} as in (6). It other words, we wish to determine the transmission rates allocation at the clients so that the maximum convergence rate is achieved while also satisfying the privacy and communication constraints. The optimization results allows us to characterize the trade-offs between convergence rate, privacy and capacity.

These questions will be addressed in the remainder of the paper.

II-C Preliminaries

A function f𝑓f is a λ𝜆\lambda-strong convex if ∀𝐰,𝐰′∈𝒲for-all𝐰superscript𝐰′𝒲\forall\ \mathbf{w},\mathbf{w}^{\prime}\in{\cal W} and any subgradient 𝐠𝐠\mathbf{g} we have f​(𝐰′)≥f​(𝐰)+𝐠.(𝐰′−𝐰)+λ2​‖𝐰′−𝐰‖2𝑓superscript𝐰′𝑓𝐰.𝐠superscript𝐰′𝐰𝜆2superscriptnormsuperscript𝐰′𝐰2f\left(\mathbf{w}^{\prime}\right)\geq f(\mathbf{w})+\mathbf{g}\ldotp\left(\mathbf{w}^{\prime}-\mathbf{w}\right)+\frac{\lambda}{2}\left\|\mathbf{w}^{\prime}-\mathbf{w}\right\|^{2}. A function f𝑓f is μ𝜇\mu-smooth with respect to the optimum point 𝐰∗superscript𝐰∗\mathbf{w}^{\ast} i.e. ∀𝐰∈𝒲for-all𝐰𝒲\forall\ \mathbf{w}\in\mathcal{W} we have f​(𝐰)−f​(𝐰∗)≤μ2​‖𝐰−𝐰∗‖2𝑓𝐰𝑓superscript𝐰∗𝜇2superscriptnorm𝐰superscript𝐰∗2f(\mathbf{w})-f(\mathbf{w}^{\ast})\leq\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}^{\ast}\right\|^{2} which normally appear in least square regressions. A function f𝑓f is L𝐿L-Lipschitz continuous if ∀𝐰,𝐰′for-all𝐰superscript𝐰′\forall\ \mathbf{w},\mathbf{w}^{\prime} we have ‖f​(𝐰′)−f​(𝐰)‖≤L​|𝐰′−𝐰|norm𝑓superscript𝐰′𝑓𝐰𝐿superscript𝐰′𝐰\left\|f\left(\mathbf{w}^{\prime}\right)-f\left(\mathbf{w}\right)\right\|\leq L\left|\mathbf{w}^{\prime}-\mathbf{w}\right|, [11].

III Main Results

For the problem formulation in Sec. II, we provide an upper bound on the convergence rate in (II-B). To do so, we design a communication and computation scheme referred to as binomial LDP-QSGD (BinLDP-QSGD) which is comprised of a number of elements, each covered in this section in a separate subsection: a quantization scheme, in Sec. III-A, and a binomial privacy-preserving mechanism, in Sec. III-B. The performance of the overall scheme is presented in Th. 1 in Sec. III-C. This is specifically investigated in solving a convex learning problem minimizing a convex function ℓ¯¯ℓ\bar{\ell} using unbiased estimates of gradients, [11]. More formally, assume that 𝒲⊆ℝd𝒲superscriptℝ𝑑{\cal W}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{d} is a convex set and ℓ¯:𝒲→ℝd:¯ℓ→𝒲superscriptℝ𝑑\bar{\ell}:{\cal W}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{d} is a differentiable, convex and smooth function. Applying SGD for a finite number of iterations T𝑇T, the goal is to bound the convergence ℓ¯​(𝐰T)−ℓ¯​(𝐰∗)¯ℓsubscript𝐰𝑇¯ℓsuperscript𝐰∗\bar{\ell}(\mathbf{w}_{T})-\bar{\ell}(\mathbf{w}^{\ast}) in the expectation sense assuming that ℓ¯¯ℓ\bar{\ell} achieves its minimum 𝐰∗∈𝒲superscript𝐰∗𝒲\mathbf{w}^{\ast}\in{\cal W}. A standard convergence analysis [11] assumes three properties for ℓ¯¯ℓ\bar{\ell} as in Sec. II-C: (i) ℓ¯¯ℓ\bar{\ell} is a λ𝜆\lambda-strong convex, (ii) ℓ¯¯ℓ\bar{\ell} is μ𝜇\mu-smooth with respect to the optimum point 𝐰∗superscript𝐰∗\mathbf{w}^{\ast}, and ℓ¯¯ℓ\bar{\ell} has L𝐿L-Lipschitz continuous gradients.

III-A Multi-Level QSGD

When communication among PS and client is subject to a cardinality constraint, one can consider a variation of SGD in which gradients are quantized before transmission. Such variation of the classic set up is termed quantized SGD (QSGD): in the proposed scheme, we consider a multilevel version of the element-wise QSGD that is described as follows for j𝑗j-th element g=𝐠i,jt𝑔superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑖𝑗𝑡g=\mathbf{g}_{i,j}^{t} of the gradient vector of client i𝑖i at iteration t𝑡t. we drop the indices corresponding to these variables for simplicity. At each iteration, each client quantizes uniformly and equally each element g𝑔g of its local gradient vector 𝐠𝐠\mathbf{g} into l𝑙l levels such that it lies in [−G,G]𝐺𝐺[-G,G]. This can be done by a simple clipping process so that −G≤g≤G𝐺𝑔𝐺-G\leq g\leq G where G𝐺G is sent by the PS to all clients at the beginning of each iteration. The quantized values are spaced with step s=2​G/(l−1)𝑠2𝐺𝑙1s=2G/\left(l-1\right). Then, the stochastic procedure assigns the quantized value QG,l​(g)subscriptQ𝐺𝑙𝑔{\rm Q}_{G,l}\left(g\right) to the element g𝑔g as

QG,l​(g)={B​(r+1)w.p.g−B​(r)sB​(r)w.p.B​(r+1)−gs,subscriptQ𝐺𝑙𝑔cases𝐵𝑟1w.p.𝑔𝐵𝑟𝑠𝐵𝑟w.p.𝐵𝑟1𝑔𝑠\displaystyle{\rm Q}_{G,l}\left(g\right)=\left\{\begin{array}[]{cc}B(r+1)&\!\!\!\textrm{w.p.}\ \ \frac{g-B(r)}{s}\\ B(r)&\!\textrm{w.p.}\ \ \frac{B(r+1)-g}{s},\end{array}\right. (13)

where r∈[0,l)𝑟0𝑙r\in[0,l), l≥2𝑙2l\geq 2, and B​(r)𝐵𝑟B(r) denote respectively the index and the bin to which the element of local gradient belongs. r𝑟r is such that g∈[B​(r),B​(r+1))𝑔𝐵𝑟𝐵𝑟1g\in\left.\left[B(r),B(r+1)\right.\right) and B​(r)𝐵𝑟B(r) is given as

B​(r)≜−G+r​s.≜𝐵𝑟𝐺𝑟𝑠B(r)\triangleq-G+rs.\vspace{-1mm} (14)

III-B Binomial privacy-preserving mechanism

A simple and widely-used method for preserving privacy is to add Gaussian noise to the local gradients. While this mechanism is beneficial in practice, it is not suitable when transmitting quantized local gradients. An alternative privacy mechanism is presented in [6]: here an i.i.d artificial noise 𝐧𝐧\mathbf{n} with binomial-distributed elements, having parameters m𝑚m and p𝑝p as Bin​(m,p)Bin𝑚𝑝{\rm Bin}(m,p), is added in a scaled unbiased manner after quantization. Accordingly, each client perturbs the quantized vector as:

𝐦𝐦\displaystyle\mathbf{m} =\displaystyle= Mp,m​(𝐪)=𝐪+s​(𝐧−m​p),subscriptM𝑝𝑚𝐪𝐪𝑠𝐧𝑚𝑝\displaystyle{\rm M}_{p,m}\left(\mathbf{q}\right)=\mathbf{q}+s\left(\mathbf{n}-mp\right), (15)

and encodes as 𝐱=XR​(𝐦)𝐱subscriptX𝑅𝐦\mathbf{x}={\rm X}_{R}\left(\mathbf{m}\right). As a result of this process, client i𝑖i transmits the codeword 𝐱it=XRit​(Mp,mit​(QGt,lit​(𝐠it)))superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑡subscriptXsuperscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑡subscriptM𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑖𝑡subscriptQsuperscript𝐺𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑙𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑖𝑡\mathbf{x}_{i}^{t}={\rm X}_{R_{i}^{t}}({\rm M}_{p,m_{i}^{t}}({\rm Q}_{G^{t},l_{i}^{t}}(\mathbf{g}_{i}^{t}))) at iteration t𝑡t. Therefore, the rate of transmission is Rit=d​log⁡(lit+mit)/Nsuperscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑡𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑙𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑖𝑡𝑁R_{i}^{t}=d\log\left(l_{i}^{t}+m_{i}^{t}\right)/N bits per channel use. Hence, for the PS to reliably extract the local gradients, it is required that this amount of information does not exceed the capacity of the MAC. The PS having decoded the transmitted vector 𝐱itsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑡\mathbf{x}_{i}^{t} from 𝐲tsuperscript𝐲𝑡\mathbf{y}^{t}, proceeds to compute the average of the local gradients as

𝐠¯t=1n​∑i∈[n]𝐱it=1n​∑i∈[n]𝐪it+sit​(𝐧it−p​mit).superscript¯𝐠𝑡1𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑡1𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐪𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐧𝑖𝑡𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑖𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{\overline{g}}^{t}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbf{x}_{i}^{t}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbf{q}_{i}^{t}+s_{i}^{t}\left(\mathbf{n}_{i}^{t}-pm_{i}^{t}\right). (16)

As 𝔼​[𝐪it]=𝐠it𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐪𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑖𝑡\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbf{q}_{i}^{t}\right]=\mathbf{g}_{i}^{t} and 𝔼​[𝐧it]=p​mit𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐧𝑖𝑡𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑖𝑡\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbf{n}_{i}^{t}\right]=pm_{i}^{t}, then 𝐠¯tsuperscript¯𝐠𝑡\mathbf{\overline{g}}^{t} is an unbiased estimation of 𝐠tsuperscript𝐠𝑡\mathbf{g}^{t} as desired. Moreover, the performance of the BinLDP-QSGD in terms of the convergence rate and the LDP can be bounded as provided in the next theorem.

Remark 1

Under the case of equal quantization levels applied by clients on the local gradients i.e. lit=ltsuperscriptsubscript𝑙𝑖𝑡superscript𝑙𝑡l_{i}^{t}=l^{t}, ∀i∈[n]for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\forall i\in[n], then the result of Thm. 1 reduces to the one in [6, Thm. 3].

As it can be seen from (1), the maximum convergence rate is achieved for higher levels of quantization and lower levels of artificial noise. However, this is in contrast with the amount of levels for which the maximum privacy is achieved. For this, lower quantization levels and higher noise parameters are required to get small values of LDP in (18) resulting in higher privacy. Hence, it is essential to propose an optimal rate allocation scheme based on some performance criteria.

III-C Results for the solution of the optimization problem

The main result of the paper is the following theorem, which characterizes the convergence of the BinLDP-QSGD algorithm.

The optimization problem stated above is an instance of constrained integer non-linear programming (INLP) . Since objective function is non-convex, the common method of relaxing the integer constraints and rounding the solution of the resulting problem as in [3] is not working in this case. Hence, it is required to go through some numerical algorithm to deal with the solution of this problem. One main result of this theorem indicates that in order to maximize the convergence rate for a given level of privacy and capacity limit, it is required to allocate the highest level of quantization and lowest level of artificial noise allowed by the capacity limit that satisfies the LDP constraint for almost equality i.e. ϵt=Δϵsuperscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡subscriptΔitalic-ϵ\epsilon^{t}=\Delta_{\epsilon}.

IV Simulation Results

To evaluate the performance of the FL model under the BinLDP-QSGD algorithm, we consider the loss function of the learning model to be the ridge regression function as

ℓ​((𝐝,v),𝐰)=(𝐰𝖳​𝐝−v)2+β2​‖𝐰‖2.ℓ𝐝𝑣𝐰superscriptsuperscript𝐰𝖳𝐝𝑣2𝛽2superscriptnorm𝐰2\displaystyle\ell\left((\mathbf{d},v),\mathbf{w}\right)=\left(\mathbf{w}^{\sf{T}}\mathbf{d}-v\right)^{2}+\frac{\beta}{2}\|\mathbf{w}\|^{2}. (21)

where β=10−3𝛽superscript103\beta=10^{-3} is the regularization parameter and the database consists of |𝒟|=104𝒟superscript104|{\cal D}|=10^{4} i.i.d sample data points (𝐝,v)𝐝𝑣(\mathbf{d},v) of dimension d=10𝑑10d=10 generated according to 𝒩​(0,𝐈d+1)𝒩0subscript𝐈𝑑1{\cal N}(0,\mathbf{I}_{d+1}). The learning algorithm is performed by K=2𝐾2K=2 users each having a dataset of size |𝒟1|=|𝒟2|=5000subscript𝒟1subscript𝒟25000|{\cal D}_{1}|=|{\cal D}_{2}|=5000 communicating with the PS through N=40𝑁40N=40 channel uses and equal average power of P1=P2=10subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃210P_{1}=P_{2}=10. Also, local gradient and quantization clipping parameters are set to Gt=Dt=4superscript𝐺𝑡superscript𝐷𝑡4G^{t}=D^{t}=4 and the output of the mechanism is intended to achieve (Δϵ,δ)=(4,10−2)subscriptΔitalic-ϵ𝛿4superscript102\left(\Delta_{\epsilon},\delta\right)=\left(4,10^{-2}\right) LDP using binomial mechanism of p=1/2𝑝12p=1/2.

The impact of 𝖲𝖭𝖱𝖲𝖭𝖱\sf{SNR} on the convergence rate of the BinLDP-QSGD algorithm is shown in Fig. 2. As the 𝖲𝖭𝖱𝖲𝖭𝖱\sf{SNR} values increase, the training loss decreases with the number of iterations and hence accuracy increases. Fig. 3 shows the convergence rate of the training algorithm in terms of the threshold LDP. As the minimum level of required privacy is increased, the training loss decreases as a result of the higher level of quantization level and lower noise parameter that can be achieved for a given fixed channel capacity as the privacy level decreases. Moreover, as the 𝖲𝖭𝖱𝖲𝖭𝖱\sf{SNR} value increases, it is possible to achieve higher level of privacy for a fixed loss. The same trend can be seen when we discuss in terms of the 𝖲𝖭𝖱𝖲𝖭𝖱\sf{SNR} values as shown in Fig. 4 where higher levels of privacy require more 𝖲𝖭𝖱𝖲𝖭𝖱\sf{SNR} values while having lower convergence rate and as the privacy measure decreases, less power is needed to reach the same loss.

V Conclusion

In this paper, the problem of efficient and private communication over MAC in FL model was considered. In this model, each client sends a digital version of the local gradient using QSGD with specific level of quantization and meanwhile adds binomial noise of discrete values to these quantized gradients in order to preserve the expected level of DP. For this FL model, the differential privacy and convergence rate were derived. The problem was formulated as to maximize the convergence rate subject to capacity and privacy constraints for which an analytic approach to the optimal solution was presented. It was shown that to meet both efficiency and privacy in FL model over MAC while having faster convergence to the optimum value, we need to work at lower transmission rates compared with the case where just the efficiency is considered.

Before addressing the privacy issue of the BinLDP-QSGD algorithm, it is required to provide the Bernstein’s inequality used in determining the privacy level of the mechanism.

Lemma 1 (Bernstein’s inequality)

Assume that X1,X2,…,Xnsubscript𝑋1subscript𝑋2…subscript𝑋𝑛X_{1},X_{2},\dots,X_{n} are n𝑛n independent random variables of zero mean and finite variance i.e. 𝔼​(Xi)=0𝔼subscript𝑋𝑖0\mathbb{E}(X_{i})=0 and 𝕍​AR​(Xi)=σi2𝕍ARsubscript𝑋𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖\mathbb{V}{\rm AR}(X_{i})=\sigma^{2}_{i} having |Xi|≤Msubscript𝑋𝑖𝑀|X_{i}|\leq M with probability 1, then for any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0,

Pr​(∑i∈[n]Xi≥2​∑i∈[n]σi2​ln⁡(1δ)+23​M​ln⁡(1δ))≤δ.Prsubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑋𝑖2subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖1𝛿23𝑀1𝛿𝛿\displaystyle\textsf{Pr}\left(\sum_{i\in[n]}X_{i}\geq\sqrt{2\sum_{i\in[n]}\sigma^{2}_{i}\ln\left(\frac{1}{\delta}\right)}+\frac{2}{3}M\ln\left(\frac{1}{\delta}\right)\right)\leq\delta. (25)
